bfyJZmJr6u4.title: The 4 Types of Diabetes Explained
bfyJZmJr6u4.description:
Groundbreaking Stanford research shows that type 2 diabetes isn’t just one disease... it’s at least four. Using deep metabolic profiling, scientists uncovered four distinct biological drivers: muscle insulin resistance, beta cell dysfunction, impaired incretin response, and liver glucose dysregulation. Nick Norwitz explains why this discovery changes everything — and how machine learning could unlock more personalized treatments for the future of diabetes.

Watch the full video here: https://youtu.be/mCrc4gfbK2o

Learn more here: https://open.substack.com/pub/staycuriousmetabolism/p/types-four-of-diabetes-what-new-technologies?r=40ekz2&utm_campaign=post&utm_medium=web&showWelcomeOnShare=true

#diabetes #type2diabetes #bloodsugar #insulinresistance #betacells #glucose #metabolichealth #stanford #medicalresearch #healthscience #scientificdiscussion #machinelearning #personalizedmedicine #evidencebased #staycurious

BoovpSMiMNI.title: Could This Gut Hormone Help with Depression? (New Research)
BoovpSMiMNI.description:
For references and a written breakdown, see the StayCurious Metabolism Newsletter: https://staycuriousmetabolism.substack.com/p/the-microbiomemood-link-a-three-ingredient?r=40ekz2 

Metabolic Psychiatry Letter: https://staycuriousmetabolism.substack.com/p/metabolic-psychiatry-pseudoscience?r=40ekz2 

For all letters, see https://StayCuriousMetabolism.com 

Can gut bacteria really treat depression? Emerging research suggests they might. In this video, we dive into a groundbreaking study published in Cell Metabolism that reveals the surprising link between the microbiome and mental health.

Scientists discovered that people with depression often have lower levels of homo-vanillic acid (HVA), a dopamine-related neurotransmitter, along with fewer gut microbes that produce it. In animal models, replenishing either specific gut bacteria (Bifidobacterium longum and Roseburia intestinalis) or HVA consistently reduced depressive symptoms.
We’ll explore the science behind the gut-brain connection, why HVA is important for mental health, and how probiotics, fermented foods, and tyrosine-rich foods can support mental health. While this is not medical advice, it opens an exciting frontier in psychiatry and emphasizes the profound link between your gut and brain health. Treat the gut, and you may also be helping the mind.

Learn more about how treating your gut could positively impact your mind. Share this video if you found it helpful and subscribe for more science-backed insights on mental health, microbiome health, and metabolic health.

Referenced Videos
Fermented Foods: https://youtu.be/wMqBkz2z7wY 
Anxiety and Inflammation: https://youtu.be/9azjuXdSYSg 
Depression Autophagy: https://youtu.be/MCCb5VkckU0

Chapters:

0:00 – Can Gut Bacteria Really Treat Depression? Exploring the Microbiome's Role
1:30 – Human Studies: HVA Levels & Depression Link
3:50 – Animal Models: Gut–Brain Connection and Depression
6:15 – Key Bacteria: Bifidobacterium longum & Roseburia intestinalis

HvJ2kzdBGOk.title: New Science on How Gut Bacteria Control Your Appetite
HvJ2kzdBGOk.description:
Your appetite may not be entirely your own. New research published in Nature reveals a groundbreaking discovery: a “sixth sense” scientists are calling the “Neurobiotic Sense,” where gut bacteria directly influence hunger and satiety signals.  The message isn’t fatalistic, you’re not just a puppet of your microbes. Instead, this science highlights how deeply interconnected we are with the microbial world inside us, and how understanding this connection can empower us to make better choices for gut health, appetite control, and long-term metabolic health.

mCrc4gfbK2o.title: Stanford’s Top Researcher (Michael Snyder) Reveals What Really Causes Diabetes
mCrc4gfbK2o.description:
In this conversation, I had the pleasure of talking with Stanford’s Professor Michael Snyder, one of the world’s leading voices in precision medicine, and one of my personal research heroes. We break down his lab’s groundbreaking research that reveals how type 2 diabetes is not one disease but four diseases. We discuss the nuances of the science and practical lifestyle takeaways drawn from this and other work. If you’re interested in cutting-edge health tech, the role of wearables in preventive medicine, or how to leverage your own biomarkers for long-term wellness, this conversation is for you.

For a written breakdown of this work, including links and references, see this StayCurious Metabolism Newsletter: https://staycuriousmetabolism.substack.com/p/types-four-of-diabetes-what-new-technologies?r=40ekz2 

Statin GLP-1 Video: https://youtu.be/3rbJnKnhg3s 

LDL 574 Letter: Coming Soon

Homovanillic Acid Letter: https://staycuriousmetabolism.substack.com/p/the-microbiomemood-link-a-three-ingredient?r=40ekz2 

‘Grapes-to-Potato Ratio’ 
After an 8-16 hour overnight fast, measure 300 grams (roughly 2.75 cups) of frozen shredded potatoes. Microwave until hot. Measure your glycaemic response on a continuous glucose monitor and note the difference between your baseline glucose and peak glucose. We will call this “Delta Peak Potato.” On another day after an overnight fast, measure 275 grams of red grapes (roughly 55 medium sized grapes) and replicate the procedure to acquire “Delta Peak Grape.”  If the ratio of the “Delta Peak Potato / Delta Peak Grape” is higher, it indicates more muscle insulin resistance. While a true predictive model with sensitivity and specificity measures has not yet been formalized, a ratio above 1.2 provides a roughly 80% sensitivity for detecting muscle insulin resistance.

mnnOxrRh5ro.title: How to Outsmart Your Obesity Genes
mnnOxrRh5ro.description:
What causes obesity? What is the role of genetics in weight gain? Are some people genetically predisposed to carry excess body fat? And how do we reconcile conflicting beliefs about obesity in today’s society? Obesity isn’t just about the calories we consume—it’s about how our body processes them. Genetics, metabolism, and the microbiome all play a crucial role in determining how our bodies store fat.

In this video, we’ll answer these questions and more. I’ll share the results of my alarming genetic report and explore how insulin resistance, leptin, habits, trauma, the gut microbiome, and more contribute to obesity. Let’s dive in!

For all the references, links, and a written breakdown, see the associated StayCurious Metabolism Newsletter: https://open.substack.com/pub/staycuriousmetabolism/p/my-genetics-say-im-obese-the-truth?r=40ekz2&utm_campaign=post&utm_medium=web&showWelcomeOnShare=true

pCDXyL9YWpA.title: The 10 Worst Vegetables for IBS – And How to Digest Them
pCDXyL9YWpA.description:
You’re eating clean and healthy—or so you think—but your gut feels like a balloon about to pop. What’s going on? While vegetables are considered a cornerstone of a healthy diet, some can cause uncomfortable gastrointestinal symptoms like bloating, constipation, diarrhea, and flatulence—especially at the most inconvenient times.

In this video, we’ll explore the top 10 vegetables that are difficult to digest and often lead to digestive distress. We’ll break down (pun intended) into the science behind bloating and other gut symptoms and explore the biological reasons these veggies can wreak havoc on your digestion. You’ll learn effective, science-backed strategies for improving vegetable digestibility, including preparation methods and targeted enzymatic support. By the end of the video, you’ll be armed with the knowledge to make these veggies more gut-friendly and turn yourself into a gut-health expert.

But have you ever wondered How physical activity slows aging at the cellular level? In this video, we review a fascinating new study in which scientists uncover that the molecule betaine is responsible for many of the anti-inflammatory, metabolic, and geroprotective effects of exercise.
We explore what this discovery means, what it doesn’t, and how betaine works in the body to support longevity, mitochondrial function, and inflammation reduction. Plus, we highlight dietary sources of betaine, including foods that naturally support your metabolic health and exercise recovery.

2doAS18X9kA.title: The Diabetes Status Quo is Unacceptable! Dr. Koutnik Speaks Out
2doAS18X9kA.description:
In this powerful and personal conversation, Dr. Andrew Koutnik, PhD—researcher in metabolism and chronic disease—shares how being diagnosed with Type 1 Diabetes as a teenager radically shaped his life and scientific path. What started as a personal health challenge became a lifelong mission to understand how nutrition, metabolism, and disease intersect.

We dive into the physiological complexity of Type 1 Diabetes, how it differs from Type 2, and how Andrew’s experience living with the condition gives him a unique perspective as both a patient and a scientist. From insulin to exercise, from blood sugar spikes to long-term health risks, this episode brings nuance to diabetes management and chronic disease science.

Whether you're living with diabetes, supporting someone who is, or simply passionate about metabolic health, this is a conversation you don’t want to miss.

You follow Dr Andrew Koutnik on X @AKoutnik, and learn more at https://andrewkoutnik.com

P7CZvAnB53E.title: The NEW Microbial Molecule Linking Diabetes and Heart Disease
P7CZvAnB53E.description:
What if one molecule produced by your gut bacteria could quietly sabotage your blood sugar and contribute to atherosclerosis? Meet imidazole propionate (ImP)—a microbial molecule formed from the amino acid histidine by gut bacteria, now deeply metabolically linked to both diabetes and heart disease.

A groundbreaking 2025 study published in Nature revealed that ImP was associated with atherosclerosis in two independent human cohorts and even triggered atherosclerosis in animal models. But that’s just the start. There’s more to the story than the internet is telling you. In this video, we explore delve into the nuances and whether you can modify your ImP levels to reduce your risk of heart disease and improve metabolic health.

d5bwEQtjfzk.title: Weighted Vests Cause Weight Loss - But Not for the Reason You Think
d5bwEQtjfzk.description:
For more information on this topic and all the references, see the associated StayCurious Newsletter: https://staycuriousmetabolism.substack.com/p/how-weighted-vests-trick-your-body?r=40ekz2

All my newsletters can be found at https://StayCuriousMetabolism.com . Subscribing to the newsletter is a great way to support me. 

Description:
Remarkably, loading your body with a weighted vest may send a signal from your bones to your brain, helping decrease appetite, leading to weight loss. While it may sound like science fiction, there is actual metabolic science behind the concept. This is known as the Gravitostat Hypothesis! Exciting research is showing how strategically loading your body with mechanical resistance can signal your brain to reduce hunger and promote fat burning. 
In this video, we break down how weighted vests, hunger regulation, and appetite control work together to enhance weight management. I’ll provide practical tips on how to incorporate this simple technique into your routine. You might just drop pounds by strapping them on first!

B-BKFux8wlY.title: Processed Meat Danger? The Science Behind the Health Debate
B-BKFux8wlY.description:
Processed meat often gets a bad reputation, with media headlines portraying it as a metabolic health time bomb, comparable to sugary snacks and soda. But most articles like this leave out critical nuances — the kind that matter to your health decisions. 

While some processed meats may pose risks, not all processed meats are created equal. Meat itself is not inherently unhealthy, and many of the concerns about processed meats are based on incomplete research. In this video, we break down some of the nuances, providing insights into the weak evidence behind these claims.

We’ll discuss the precautionary principle and show you how to make smarter, informed decisions that can enhance your overall health. This isn’t about giving hot dogs a free pass, it’s about measuring up the claims so you can decide for yourself what you want on your plate.

STAYCURIOUS NEWSLETTERS
For a full written breakdown, including all the references, see the associated StayCurious Newsletter: https://staycuriousmetabolism.substack.com/p/processed-meat-and-health-the-existing?r=40ekz2

VDJGCw-enhI.title: Seed Oils Need Nuance and Humility: Deep Dive with Physionic
VDJGCw-enhI.description:
In this in-depth conversation with Dr. Nic Verhoeven, PhD. creator of Physionic, we explore the controversial world of seed oils and their impact on health. Together, we – “the Nicks” –delves into the science behind seed oils, separating fat from fiction. Importantly, we try to approach this topic with the nuance and humility we both feel is deserves. 

This isn’t about what we know for certain as much as it is about what the biomedical and scientific community should admit we don’t know but need to study further. Get ready for a thought-provoking discussion on nutrition science, the impact of seed oils on metabolic health, and practical insights to make more informed dietary choices.

Follow Nic Verhoeven at Physionic YouTube Channel https://www.youtube.com/@Physionic 

To Learn More about Seed Oils see my prior video on topic, as well as a recent Newsletter covering a key paper that Nic and I briefly discuss in this interview. Hint: It’s all about “Perspective.”

Prior Seed Oil video https://youtu.be/3rwbL5HrRUc

t1LruyVfGCc.title: NEW 2025 Meta-Analysis: RCTs Don’t Support Restricting Saturated Fat
t1LruyVfGCc.description:
For decades, we've been told that saturated fat is harmful to heart health. But is it finally time to stop blaming butter and other sources of saturated fat for heart disease? In this video, we dive into a new 2025 meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) that reveals “the evidence available from RCTs does not support saturated fat restriction for the prevention of cardiovascular disease.”

The study challenges long-standing beliefs about dietary fat and its role in heart health, sparking a crucial conversation about how we approach heart disease prevention and cholesterol management. We’ll explore the implications of this new evidence, discuss why there's still confusion around this issue, and offer practical insights on healthy fats, dietary guidelines, and cardiovascular health.

Stay tuned for key takeaways from this meta-analysis and learn why saturated fat might not be the culprit we've been led to believe.

REFERENCES AND MORE INFORMATION
A written breakdown of these data will all references hyperlinked can be found in the June 16, 2025, letter at: http://StayCuriousMetabolism.com . The letter includes descriptions on how to understand forest plots, my conflicts of interest, which are certainly not aligned with “Big Butter” – quite the opposite, actually.

fAuP08-kQYQ.title: The Science of Fecal Transplants for Pain
fAuP08-kQYQ.description:
What if poop could treat chronic pain? I’m not joking. As strange as it sounds, this question is backed by serious science. New research, including an exciting human trial, shows that fecal microbiome transplants could potentially treat chronic pain disorders like fibromyalgia. If you or a loved one have ever suffered from chronic pain, this video is for you. 

We’ll dive into the latest findings and explore how gut health and the microbiome might hold the key to pain relief. Stay until the end for an exclusive interview clip with the first author of the study! Don’t miss out on this fascinating glimpse into the future of chronic pain treatment. Let’s explore how fecal transplants could revolutionize pain management.

TUNmaIF1Ygc.title: This Saturated Fat Can Burn Fat: A Milkshake Experiment
TUNmaIF1Ygc.description:
Saturated fat is one of the most misunderstood nutrients in nutrition. Part of this misunderstanding stems from a common stereotype: saturated fats are often lumped together as a single entity, when in fact, they are a diverse group of fatty acids. In this video, I’m going to prove the point by reviewing scientific data showing how one specific saturated fat, stearic acid, positively influences fat metabolism and increases fat burning at the mitochondrial level.

I’ll also provide you with a broader framework to understand these findings and general principles of nutrition, while giving you practical takeaways that will help you make better dietary choices. These tips include where to source this beneficial fat in your diet, and I’ll explore its other health benefits, such as reducing visceral fat, lowering blood pressure, and even fighting colon cancer. Let’s dive into the science behind saturated fat’s role in health...

STAYCURIOUS NEWSLETTERS
For a full written breakdown, including all the references, see the associated StayCurious Newsletter: https://staycuriousmetabolism.substack.com/p/this-saturated-fat-can-burn-fat-a?r=40ekz2

3rwbL5HrRUc.title: Seed Oil vs. Tallow Debate: What’s Really Best for Your Health?
3rwbL5HrRUc.description:
The Seed Oil Debate is one of the most heated topics in nutrition today. It's a cornerstone issue in the growing “Make America Healthy Again” #MAHA movement, sparking a counterculture push to replace industrialized plant fats (aka seed oils) with animal fats. Calls to “Bring Back Tallow Fries” to fast food chains like McDonald's have fueled this debate. But this video isn't just about French fries—it's about something much bigger.

We’re diving into the science behind the seed oil controversy and exploring the broader issue of how we navigate conflicting data in nutrition science. The confusion between animal fats vs. plant fats and the benefits of seed oils vs. tallow is caused by opposing evidence from different sources, each side believing they have the best argument. Instead of resolving these inconsistencies, the issue is dismissed and fueled by propaganda. In this video, we’ll break down the facts, exploring the health benefits of tallow, animal fats, and seed oils, offering a deeper understanding of this ongoing debate.

Let’s dig into the nuances of this conversation and separate the facts from the myths.

STAYCURIOUS NEWSLETTERS
For a full written breakdown, including all the references, see the associated StayCurious Newsletter: https://staycuriousmetabolism.substack.com/p/are-tallow-fries-a-big-fat-scam-untangling?r=40ekz2 

All letters can be found at https://StayCuriousMetabolism.com . Subscribing to the newsletter is a great way to support me.

If you know me, you know one of my favorite things to do in this world is distill these scientific discoveries into something digestible yet nuanced, so that we can share in the awe of biology, metabolism, and human health together. 

But today’s video is something new for my channel. This is a rapid-fire, high-yield rundown of my 10 favorite original research findings published in top scientific journals over the past year. We’re going to talk about topics spanning brain health, mental health, the microbiome, heart health, muscle function, hormones, gut health, neuroplasticity, immunology, and more.

As we dive into these groundbreaking findings, you'll gain valuable insights into how cutting-edge research is transforming our approach to preventative health and personalized medicine. New data show how inflammation can act directly on the brain to promote (or soothe) anxiety. In this video, we will break down these new findings, explain what they mean for your mental health, and provide you with practical takeaways to improve your quality of life. j0ClcgNBeec.title: I Ate 2000 Calories of Saturated Fat a Day—Here's What It Did to My Cholesterol
j0ClcgNBeec.description:
For 4 weeks, I ate 2,000 calories per day of saturated fat to see what it would do to my cholesterol levels. Spoiler alert: NOTHING. That’s 222 grams of saturated fat per day, and my total and LDL "bad" cholesterol levels remained the same. In this video, I break down why this happened and explain why this isn't just clickbait—it's a science-backed demonstration that will challenge conventional thinking about cholesterol, saturated fat, and cardiovascular health. We'll dive deep into how dietary fat influences cholesterol levels, the role of LDL and HDL, and why it's important to rethink what we know about fat consumption. Prepare to have your curiosity piqued and learn the real science behind these surprising results that appear to defy mainstream perspectives cholesterol.

To get your own CardioChek from Blood Chek Medical, follow this link. Use Discount Code “DrNicholasNorwitz” for $50 off CardioChek Plus Analyzer: https://bloodchekmedical.com/pages/cardiochek-dr-nicholas-norwitz/aff=2

Chapters 
0:00 – Consuming 2000 Calories from Saturated Fat: What Happened? 
1:02 – How My Baseline Ketogenic Diet Affected My Cholesterol 
1:52 – Switching to a Saturated Fat-Rich Diet: The Details 
3:08 – Surprising Result: My Cholesterol Didn’t Change 
3:25 – Understanding Why My Cholesterol Remained the Same 
8:36 – Why Did I Test Saturated Fat’s Impact on Cholesterol? 
11:01 – How to Test Your Cholesterol Levels at Home
12:39 – The Importance of Metabolic Context in Cholesterol Levels 

LDL cholesterol levels were graphed as ‘baseline normalized,’ i.e. as a ratio of LDL cholesterol at a given timepoint relative to baseline LDL cholesterol level for three reasons (i) Relative change, not absolute value, is most pertinent to the point(s) demonstrated by the experiment (ii) Given Lean Mass Hyper-Responder physiology, my baseline LDL-C on a ketogenic diet – irrespective of the fatty acid composition of that diet – is high. This is not the case when I’m on a diet including carbohydrates, as we’ve published. In prior content, audience has become fixated on absolute numbers relative to their own and attempted to use that as justification for personal choices. The point of the video is a physiologic demonstration, not a “dietary hall pass,” as stated explicitly in the video. (iii) We’ve published the absolute numbers in several papers in the peer-reviewed literature. A collection of papers can be found: https://cholesterolcode.com/papers/

iVwDJqJiTEY.title: Lp(a) Explained: Genetics, Risk, and What You Can Actually Do
iVwDJqJiTEY.description:
Lp(a), lipoprotein(a) is a major genetic risk factor for heart disease and one of the most talked-about topics in modern cardiology. It plays a significant role as a causal risk factor for cardiovascular disease and is thought to be largely genetically determined. What do you do if you’re genetically cursed, like me, with high Lp(a) levels?  In this video, I promise on my own heart health, you'll gain a deeper understanding of Lp(a): what it is, why it’s so important for your heart and metabolic health, and what actionable steps you can take to manage your cardiovascular risk.

To give you a roadmap, here’s what we’ll cover in the 8 chapters:
1. Defining Lp(a) 
2. Guidelines on measuring Lp(a) and risk thresholds 
3. Medications in development to reduce Lp(a) by as much as 99% 
4. How to reduce cardiovascular risk 
5. Why statins increase Lp(a) and what this means 
6. Saturated fat can lower Lp(a) level
7. Oxidized phospholipids as the cargo of Lp(a) 
8. Nuance notes for the nerds.

This video will help you navigate the complexities of Lp(a), cholesterol management, and cardiovascular disease prevention. Get ready to learn how to take charge of your heart health and make informed decisions.

All references are hyperlinked in the associated Newsletter, here: https://staycuriousmetabolism.substack.com/p/lpa-explained-genetics-risk-and-what?r=40ekz2 

All StayCurious Metabolism Newsletters can be found at http://StayCuriousMetabolism.com

kflUjpHiaHo.title: How to Choose REAL Extra Virgin Olive Oil: A Practical Guide
kflUjpHiaHo.description:
Olive Oil Lover's Club! This link for 10% off: https://tidd.ly/3FDeHHb

Is your extra virgin olive oil actually extra virgin… or just extra fake? Up to 80% of "extra virgin" olive oils on store shelves aren’t actually extra virgin. They’re often oxidized, stripped of their healthiest compounds, or even cut with cheap oils like soybean or canola. And that means… the oil you think is fueling your health might actually be undermining it. But don’t worry—today, I’ll show you how to spot the frauds, choose the best extra virgin olive oil, and even put your olive oil to the ultimate test. IAc_7r_hVI8.title: The Scientific Truth Behind the Sugar Diet (I Was NOT Expecting This)
IAc_7r_hVI8.description:
If you haven’t been following, the sugar diet is exactly what it sounds like: a low-protein, low-fat, high-sugar diet. Some influencers are eating up to 800 grams of sugary carbs per day! But they’re reporting fat loss. It sounds crazy, but a new scientific study sheds light on how this could work for some people. And, at the same time, it debunks the sugar diet. After watching this video, you’ll understand more about the sugar diet, hormonal balance, fat cell metabolism, and how the sugar diet is actually similar to extreme ketogenic diets. This isn’t a gotcha’ video. It’s an attempt to turn a fad diet into deeper metabolic understanding, so you can make informed choices about fat loss, body composition, and dieting strategies. 

Sugar Diet Newsletter: https://staycuriousmetabolism.substack.com/p/the-sugar-diet-worksbut-not-for-the?r=40ekz2 

All StayCurious Metabolism Newsletters can be found at https://StayCuriousMetabolism.com

Fruit Video: https://youtu.be/QjJr5qvRkBk

Primary Reference: Nicolaisen TS et al. Dietary protein restriction elevates FGF21 levels and energy requirements to maintain body weight in lean men. Nature Metabolism, 2025.

Links to all references and Nuance Notes can be found in the associated Newsletter, above.

Teaser Nuance Note on Ketogenic Diets and FGF-21, Does a ketogenic diet increase FGF-21 sensitivity? Interestingly, while it appears protein restriction on a 4:1 ketogenic diet (90% fat) increases FGF-21 in animals, data in humans aren’t as compelling. However, based on the available data, it’s reasonable to speculate this may be in part because ketogenic are classically associated with weight loss and may simultaneously increase FGF-21 sensitivity via upregulation of β-klotho and other receptors and components of FGF-21 signaling pathways. See the letter for more.

_t-6qirB5-I.title: The Power of CAC = 0: When Does LDL Matter?
_t-6qirB5-I.description:
Medical management of heart disease is evolving rapidly with the advancement of cardiac imaging technology. These innovations provide better insights into personalized medicine, allowing us to understand cholesterol levels in a new light. The outdated idea that high cholesterol is always dangerous is being challenged by emerging research. In this video, we dive into data that shows high LDL cholesterol isn’t always a useful risk factor for heart disease. 

This isn’t an excuse to disregard your doctor’s advice, but we aim to arm you with the facts, scientific evidence, and logic to help you make informed decisions. In this video, we will also give you the data to back up your next conversation with your healthcare provider. 

If you’re interested in taking a proactive approach to your cardiovascular health, let’s dive in. Remember, this is not medical advice—but empowered decision-making can change your health trajectory. Let’s get started!

For a written breakdown and all references, see the associated StayCurious Metabolism Newsletter: https://staycuriousmetabolism.substack.com/p/the-power-of-cac-0-does-ldl-cholesterol?r=40ekz2

mfo5L8OxYhU.title: Is this the REAL Root Cause of Autoimmune Disease?
mfo5L8OxYhU.description:
What if all autoimmune diseases were stemming from the same source, from a seed planted 2 billion years ago that’s just beginning to flower? That might sound wild—but it’s actually the central thesis of a new paper published in Nature which proposes that many autoimmune diseases, if not all of them, may be driven by the failure of a relationship that began 2 billion years ago: the one between your body and your mitochondria. 
In this video, I’ll break down mitochondrial dysfunction, how it might be the root cause of autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, multiple sclerosis, and type 1 diabetes. I’ll also give you a list of practical health tips for boosting mitochondrial health. Whether you’re dealing with autoimmune disease or just want to understand how mitochondrial failure could be impacting your health, this video has you covered!

For all references, please see the associated StayCurious Newsletter. I do provide all references. If you want them, they’re just two clicks away. https://staycuriousmetabolism.substack.com/p/is-this-the-real-root-cause-of-autoimmune?r=40ekz2

Caesar Dressing:
1. Dissolve 1 can of anchovies in avocado oil or macadamia oil over low heat.
2. Blend with 2 large egg yolks and 2 tsp of lemon juice.
3. With the blender on, drizzle in macadamia oil, avocado oil, or extra virgin olive oil until it starts to adopt a mayo-like consistency.
4. Add about 100 g of Manchego cheese to thicken it up.
5. Adjust the consistency by thinning with more lemon juice or water to your desired texture.
6. Store in the fridge – it will likely solidify, which is perfectly fine.
7. For extra creaminess, add some heavy cream while blending.

This recipe isn’t particularly scientific. Customize it with your own variations – find out what works for your tongue and body

_n0Ssa_y7Z4.title: Cells Don’t Have a Political Ideology
_n0Ssa_y7Z4.description:
Cells don’t have politics. But nutrition, metabolism, and health sciences are extremely political. How do we handle this discrepancy? How do we navigate towards objective biological truth, science-based health information, and practical wellness solutions in a world where just four letters — #MAHA — can divide a room?

In this video, I attempt to tackle that difficult topic in a way that is BOLD and direct but also nuanced, inclusive, and open-minded. The video also serves as a response to a recent widely circulated podcast between health and fitness leaders Mark Hyman and Andrew Huberman, who dropped a bomb about me during their latest episode.

We explore how scientific discussion, personal identity, and public health messaging collide—and how we can move forward with curiosity and clarity.

-S_jk5EdOzk.title: Your body makes THIS?! Unexpected Metabolism Booster Explained
-S_jk5EdOzk.description:
What if I told you that Cyanide—one of the most infamous poisons in history—might actually be involved in essential metabolic pathways, potentially keeping you alive and enhancing your mitochondrial function and cellular energy production?! Sounds wild, but it’s true. Extraordinary new science reveals how the body makes its own endogenous cyanide and how cyanide then acts to boost cellular respiration and metabolism and even protect cells from death. 

In this video, we break down the data and reveal what you can (safely) do to potentially support and optimize functional cyanide signaling. If you’re a nerd who loves to sit in awe of the mind-bending realities of how our bodies work, this one is for you!

For a links, references and written breakdown of these data, see the associated Stay Curious Metabolism Newsletter: https://open.substack.com/pub/staycuriousmetabolism/p/is-cyanide-an-essential-nutrient?r=40ekz2&utm_campaign=post&utm_medium=web&showWelcomeOnShare=true

rF0c31ssn7g.title: How a Common Kitchen Spice Could Boost Brain Function and Mental Health
rF0c31ssn7g.description:
What if I told you that the kitchen spice saffron, often used in cooking and traditional medicine, could improve mood and reduce symptoms of depression? It may sound too good to be true, but that claim is supported by a growing pile of human randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and sensible biological mechanisms related to brain chemistry and inflammation. I’m going to share two of these studies, explain the neuroscience behind saffron’s antidepressant effects, and direct you to more learning. This golden spice really might be the next big thing in mental health, natural remedies, and nutritional psychiatry!

For linked scientific references, clinical studies, and a written breakdown, see the associated Stay Curious Metabolism newsletter on the benefits of saffron for mood and depression: https://staycuriousmetabolism.substack.com/p/saffron-for-depression-the-science?r=40ekz2

txgpYZH2Z9Y.title: Why High LDL Cholesterol Doesn’t Always Lead to Heart Disease
txgpYZH2Z9Y.description:
Why do some individuals with sky-high LDL cholesterol and ApoB appear resistant to heart disease, while others with lower LDL and ApoB do develop heart disease? In this video, we dive deep into one mechanism behind this paradox, exploring how cholesterol-containing particles enter the blood vessel walls and "seed" coronary plaques. We also discuss groundbreaking new data that shows a population with extremely high LDL cholesterol may actually be at lower risk for heart disease. This video challenges conventional beliefs and promotes data-driven insights over dogma. 

We’ll cover how LDL cholesterol, ApoB, and metabolic health play a role in cardiovascular risk and plaque formation while highlighting the importance of individual variability in heart disease risk.

Big New Paper, please read and share: https://www.jacc.org/doi/10.1016/j.jacadv.2025.101686

The Video: https://youtu.be/a_ROZPW9WrY

I9TOMH332eA.title: Cardiologist Reacts to BREAKING Cholesterol Research: "Data Challenges Dogma"
I9TOMH332eA.description:
What you’re about to hear is a conversation between myself and Dr. Aseem Malhotra, a renowned consultant cardiologist, and close friend of RFK Jr.. I mention that upfront to address the elephant in the room. Our conversation centers around the latest research that colleagues and I have published on LDL cholesterol, ApoB, and their implications for heart disease, particularly in the context of metabolic health.
🤔 Why are these new findings so important for understanding cardiovascular risk?

🤔 Is High LDL and ApoB dangerous in the context of Metabolic Health?

🤔 How can meditation impact heart disease prevention and overall heart health?

🤔 Why does the scientific community move slowly when it comes to adopting new research?

I encourage you to keep an open mind. Scientific narratives, health models, and medical practices evolve as new data emerges. This is the essence of the scientific method.

Please Watch THIS Video: https://youtu.be/a_ROZPW9WrY 

NEW Paper: https://www.jacc.org/doi/10.1016/j.jacadv.2025.101686

a_ROZPW9WrY.title: Game-Changing Study on Heart Health and Cholesterol: New Insights Revealed
a_ROZPW9WrY.description:
It’s FINALLY Here! After years of work, we’ve published groundbreaking, first-of-its-kind prospective clinical data that provides valuable insights into the question: Are Lean, Metabolically Healthy People with high LDL and ApoB on Ketogenic Diets at high risk for heart disease?  The results are scientifically shocking, and will, without a doubt, challenge conventional beliefs about cardiovascular health and cholesterol management. This is essential viewing for anyone interested in cardiovascular disease prevention, LDL and ApoB research, ketogenic diet safety, heart health, lipid profiles, cholesterol testing, and metabolic health optimization. This is the beginning of an important conversation. 

SHARE this paper: https://www.jacc.org/doi/10.1016/j.jacadv.2025.101686

For a written breakdown with more references, see the associated Stay Curious Metabolism Newsletter: https://open.substack.com/pub/staycuriousmetabolism/p/big-news-the-lean-mass-hyper-responder?r=40ekz2&utm_campaign=post&utm_medium=web&showWelcomeOnShare=true

28AEG_0hoig.title: Can You Outlift Aging? Science Says… YES!
28AEG_0hoig.description:
A groundbreaking, one-of-a-kind study took 139 adults spanning ages 20 to 93 and asked: What are the relative effects of aging and exercise on body composition, strength, and muscle function? The results? Surprisingly uplifting! But there’s one BIG problem with aging that even exercise can't fully reverse.

Does weightlifting slow aging? Can resistance training boost longevity? I’ll break down what the science says and give you practical strategies to maximize muscle function as you age. And if you stick around to the end, you’ll hear directly from the senior researcher behind this study!

🔗 References & Written Breakdown: https://staycuriousmetabolism.substack.com/p/aging-is-inevitable-weakness-is-a?r=40ekz2 

🔥 Related Video – Oleuropein & Muscle Strength: https://youtu.be/ljuimrT2a1s

🔹 Mitochondrial Calcium Uniporter Complex – A key protein system in mitochondria that helps shuttle calcium for energy production. Levels decline with age, potentially leading to muscle dysfunction and fatigue. See the Oleuropein & Muscles video for more insights!

Vs.

🔹 Mitochondrial Permeability Transition Pore (MPTP) – A channel that can cause mitochondrial dysfunction and cell death under stress. Could this be a major player in age-related muscle loss?

I simplified the lifespan diagrams from the paper. For those want to know, the green and red line are wildtype animals, with green being control and red being LCA treatment. The other lines (blue and brown) have the genes coding for AMPK knocked out. This helps to demonstrate the essential role of the enzyme, AMPK, in mediating the effect of LCA on lifespan.

Glossary of Terms

Conching: The process of mixing the cocoa solids, cocoa butter (and usually sugar) This process generally mellows the flavors, makes the texture smooth, but also reduces flavanol levels. 

Dutching: A process that treats cocoa beans, nibs, liquor, or powder with an alkaline solution to reduce their natural acidity.

Epicatechin: Type of flavanol found in cacao, and green and black tea.

Flavanols: Naturally occurring with antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties found in foods like cacao, berries, and tea that have been linked to cardiovascular health and cognitive function.

Seed Oils continue to be a controversial topic. Are they truly “poison” and responsible for the obesity epidemic? Or are they mostly hype and not worth worrying yourself about when you go out to eat at a restaurant or consume a snack? Is the Omega-6/3 ratio important, and what factors beyond diet influence it? Macadamia and Macadamia Oil

I’m a long-time, big-time macadamia fan. This includes the raw nuts, nut butters and the oils. While I don’t think Omega-6 PUFA are harmful per se, macadamia are the lowest Omega-6 nut and also low in oxalates, phytates and lectins, concerns for some people. They’re also packed with healthy Omega-7 fats, and incredibly versatile and delicious. The oil is also highly heat resistant, and one of my favorite cooking oils.

lDeegZ1wtAI.title: Specific Foods to Burn Visceral Fat: Randomized Controlled Trial
lDeegZ1wtAI.description:
Visceral Fat is the worst type of fat. It’s the fat that sits around your internal organs, promotes inflammation, and is specifically linked to poor cardiovascular and metabolic health. If you want to burn a particular type of fat, it’s visceral fat. In this video we walk through a Randomized Controlled Trial comparing 3 diets and highlight one particular Low-Carbohydrate Mediterranean-style diet that appears especially effective at burning away visceral fat. We also discuss foods containing compounds that might give you an edge over visceral fat to optimize your metabolic health.
 
Chapters
0:00 – Eviscerate Visceral Fat!
0:58 – Randomized Control Trial, Methods
2:55 – Randomized Control Trial, Results 
4:02 – Breaking Down the Mechanisms
6:18 – Polyphenols, Hippuric Acid and Urolithin A
7:40 – You Are an Individual!
7:50 – Closing Thoughts

Study:  Zelicha H. et al. The effect of high-polyphenol Mediterranean diet on visceral adiposity: the DIRECT PLUS randomized controlled trial. BMC Med 2022. PMID: 36175997

Glossary of Terms (Alphabetical):

- Benzoic Acid: A simple naturally occurring compound and precursor(s) to Hippuric Acid.

- Brown/Beige Fat: Type of fat tissue that burn calories as heat due to uncoupling of mitochondria. This is called “thermogenesis.” The difference between Brown and Beige fat has to do with their precursor cells. Brown fat has a different precursor than typical “white” (energy storage) fat, whereas Beige fat comes from the white fat lineage and develops increased capacity to promote thermogenesis and burn energy as heat. 

- Ellagitannins: A diverse group of polyphenols, and precursor(s) to Urolithin A.

- Hippuric Acid: A glycine derivative of benzoic acid that is made by gut bacteria and associated with more microbiome diversity.

- Subcutaneous Fat: Fat that's stored under the skin and can be pinched.

- Urolithin A: An “anti-obesity” agent that can increase energy expenditure by increasing thermogenesis in brown/beige fat. Urolithin A is not found directly in food but is made by gut microbes from ellagitannins.

- Visceral Fat: Fat stored around organs that’s inflammatory and contributes to poor metabolic health, inflammation, and cardiovascular disease.

- Wolffia Globosa, Duckweed: The smallest known flowering plant (0.004–0.008 inches in diameter) that – interestingly – contains B12 and protein and being studied for space agriculture. 

Nutritional Guide

The original plan was to create a printable one-page guide to go with this video. Unfortunately, upon deeper review, there weren’t consistent data on the specific Ellagitannin, Hippuric Acid, and Benzoic Acid contents of particular foodstuffs. Urolithin A isn’t found in food naturally. Therefore, below are listed foods by relative content of a given nutrient, understanding there is decent variation ever for a specific food item.

Ellagitannins
- Berries, especially cloudberries, artic bramble, raspberries, strawberries, and sea buckthorn. Note: High latitude berries, e.g. cloudberries and artic bramble, appear to be particularly rich in ellagitannins
- Other fruit: Pomegranate 
- Nuts: Walnuts are highest in ellagitannins, followed by Hazelnuts, Pecans and Almonds.
- Teas: Green teas and Cistus incanus tea, particularly from Turkey, Albania, and Greece
- Wine: Particularly Blackberry wine made with Andean blackberries. Some have ellagitannins contents as high as ~1200 mg/L.

Hippuric Acid and/or Benzoic Acid (benzoic acid is converted into hippuric acid)
- Berries: Including bilberries, strawberries, raspberries, and cloudberries. Note: The highest benzoic acid appears to be the Scottish Strawberry, with ~1300 mg/kg benzoic acid.
- Dairy Products: Cheese and Yogurts contain benzoic acid. Note: Fermented dairy and blue cheeses have additional probiotic benefits.

This guide was composed with help from Consensus AI. For more about Consensus, see my partners page: https://www.nicknorwitz.com/pages/partners 

Acknowledgements: 

This video and thumbnail are based on a model from my friend, Thomas DeLauer. His video was a banger, so I decided to do a replication with modification, with his awareness and permission. It’s nice to have friends with whom who you can share content ideas, hopefully to mutual benefit. Here, credit goes to Thomas for bringing these data to my attention.

67TouiKEoKs.title: World’s Strongest Man Goes Carnivore: Metabolism Scientist Explains
67TouiKEoKs.description:
Eddie Hall, who won the World’s Strongest Man in 2017 and who set the world Deadlift at 1102 lbs (500kg) has started a carnivore diet! In this video, I’ll breakdown what Eddie eats, explain how he’s losing weight on 10,000 Calories per day, discuss loose stools on carnivore, and more. 

Amendments
(i) On the solid vs liquid butter mini-experiment, people have noted butter will melt at body temperature. Of course, this is true. However, it's also true of all common fat sources, including tallow, lard and coconut oil. The idea is to control for fatty acids; thus, a comparison of olive oil versus ribeye steak would not be a good way to test the solid/liquid effect. There are alternatives, e.g. ribeye steak vs lean filet plus melted tallow; although even this is complicated by the fact the variable of distinction is the food matrix, more than the solid/liquid state. It's possible - maybe probable - that I misunderstood Shawn in our conversation and he meant that fatty meat, which is solid, will empty out of the stomach more slowly than pure fat, which is liquid or liquid at human body temperature. If this is the case, there are other ways one could test the gastric emptying rate idea, e.g. with medications that slow gastric emptying like GLP-1RA. Personally, my money is on more of an electrolyte, microbiome purge and/or fatty acid effect. But, clearly, it's highly individual.

(ii) Some people have commented that Eddie is now using Fiber supplements. For this video, I reviewed the two videos he'd posted on his carnivore diet (the initial one, and the first 30 days video). In neither of those did he mention taking fiber. So, if I omitted this detail, it was unintentional 

If you love macadamia like me - or want to try the best macadamia products on the planet ( (and maybe dipping cheese in macadamia butter, at video timestamp - 5:03) - below it my affiliate link to House of Macadamia. I've been using their products for 5 years and sincerely LOVE them.

n6UVCrKexrc.title: The Link Between Stress and the Microbiome: New Research Explained
n6UVCrKexrc.description:
Paper: https://www.cell.com/cell/fulltext/S0092-8674(24)00779-7

How does stress impact gut health? New science reveals a pathway whereby an emotion regulation center in the brain, the amygdala, signals to intestinal glands in the gut that feed particular good gut bacteria to improve gut health. Stress inhibits this pathway, leading to changes in the microbiome and “tummy troubles.” These new data provide mechanistic insights into how certain stress reduction practices, including those reviewed in this video, may help to improve gut health and reduce unpleasant symptoms – bloating, diarrhea, and constipation – plagues many of us. What’s good for the mind is good for the gut, and what good for the gut is good for the brain.

#guthealth #mentalhealth #anxietyrelief

85xZxSO4qBY.description:
Exercise is good for mental health, or so some say. But is it just psychology or associated healthy habits? No! New research in Cell Metabolism sheds light on HOW exercise improves resilience to psychological stress and exerts its anti-anxiety effects on the brain and mind. The biological story is beautiful and centers on how lactate, produced during exercise, can modify a key protein, SNAP91, that controls how brain cells talk to one another. In this video, I breakdown the data and provide practical takeaways for you to bring to the gym… and you may even save money on therapy too.

Chapters
0:00 – Joe Rogan Wisdom
0:39 – New paper on Exercise, Lactate, and Anxiety

1:50 – Brain Lactate from Exercise Reduces Anxiety 
2:49 – Lactate attaches to SNAP91 to Change Brain Metabolism
5:32 – Practical Takeaway 

Paper: https://www.cell.com/cell-metabolism/fulltext/S1550-4131(24)00289-4

-xrN4Wc73QM.title: Meat the Facts: Red Meat Causes Diabetes?
-xrN4Wc73QM.description:
Two major papers have recently made headlines, claiming a link between red meat intake and Type 2 Diabetes. The media has been grilling the story, cooking up conflict and confusion. In this video, I break down the serious limitations in those studies and explain why giving up red meat to prevent diabetes is not a fruitful endeavor.

Paper 1: Wang et al. Integration of epidemiological and blood biomarker analysis links haem iron intake to increased type 2 diabetes risk. Nature Metabolism; August 2024.

Paper 2: Li et al. Meat consumption and incident type 2 diabetes: an individual-participant federated meta-analysis of 1·97 million adults with 100 000 incident cases from 31 cohorts in 20 countries. Lancet Diabetes and Endocrinology; Sept 2024.

Carnivore Diet for Inflammatory Bowel Disease

JJQCwsy_yM8.title: Could the Carnivore Diet Revolutionize Inflammatory Bowel Disease Treatment?
JJQCwsy_yM8.description:
Paper, Carnivore for Inflammatory Bowel Disease: https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/nutrition/articles/10.3389/fnut.2024.1467475/full

Ketogenic and carnivore diets, are gaining popularity for the experimental treatment of a wide range of disorders, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). We report on 10 cases of biopsy-confirmed IBD responsive to carnivore-ketogenic diets. Clinical presentations were diverse, including six cases of ulcerative colitis and of four of Crohn’s disease. Clinical improvements were substantial and universal. Patients’ diets comprised mostly meat, eggs and animal fats. Patients report their diets are pleasurable, sustainable, and unequivocally enhance their quality of life. 

Chapters:
0:00 – Diet for Inflammatory Bowel Disease

pvIwTeXaEP0.title: How Ketones Block Cancer
pvIwTeXaEP0.description:
Keto is more than just cutting carbs. It’s about entering a unique metabolic state where your body produces ketones, powerful molecules that can play a critical role in fighting cancer. Specifically, the ketone body beta-hydroxybutyrate has been shown to inhibit key enzymes and pathways that cancer cells rely on for growth. This isn’t just about removing carbs from your diet; it’s about adding a metabolic state that could reshape cancer metabolism. I will break down the science, concisely and in a way that’s easy to understand. #Cancer #Metabolism #Ketodiet #mTOR

Paper: https://www.nature.com/articles/s42255-024-01093-w

hiCxpHDAlbs.title: Could This Common Item Really Treat Metabolic Syndrome?
hiCxpHDAlbs.description:
Levels of the ‘anti-obesity’ hormone, GLP-1, are reduced in insulin-resistance disorders, including obesity, PCOS, diabetes, metabolic syndrome, etc. Why? This is as question that’s been plaguing obesity medicine. But now, we have a mechanism. It’s not the whole picture (it hardly ever is). However, it’s a fascinating discovery that will blow your mind, if you take the time to contemplate it deeply.

I'm also on the scientific advisory board at RxSugar, a company that specializes in allulose. Unlike macadamia - which I do consume regularly - I don't have much of a sweet tooth so don't find I have much of a need for allulose. However, I always try my best to separate my personal preferences from the science, which is why I'm happy and proud to support RxSugar and their mission to displace fructose and sugar in the food supply with allulose! Among allulose's interesting properties is that it induces the release of endogenous GLP-1, albeit at lower dose equivalencies than prescription medications. Still, there are data (clinical and preclinical) that allulose can have anti-obesogenic properties. And the precise mechanism is being explored actively! There are also clinical reports of people have loss of cravings and "food noise" with allulose products, which is interesting. I wonder if one could measure a change in DMH pre-ingestion satiation neurons after an allulose bolus... perhaps we will find out in time!

fyERqDgSiMg.title: Sweet Surprise: The Science of Sucralose will leave your head Spinning
fyERqDgSiMg.description:
Paper: https://www.cell.com/cell-metabolism/pdf/S1550-4131(20)30057-7.pdf 

Dosing used in primary experiment: 7 beverages over ~2 weeks each containing 0.06 g sucralose (0 Kcal) vs 30.38 g sucrose (120 Kcal) vs or 0.06 g sucralose and 31.83 g of the non-sweet carbohydrate maltodextrin (120Kcal). If there are 12 mg sucralose in a single packet of Splenda, then it's equivalent to ~2.5 Splenda packs per day (or 5 packs [5 * 0.012 = 0.06], every other day) for 2 weeks.

Quote: "After a mean duration of 4.7 years of carbohydrate restriction-induced elevations in #LDL-cholesterol [mean 272 mg/dl, max 591 mg/dl], a metabolically healthy cohort of subjects on a ketogenic diet [#LMHR] did not have greater atherosclerotic burden than participants from a population based cohort with similar risk profiles but markedly lower [123 mg/dl] LDL-C." 

JAMA Cardiology Paper: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32049305/ 

Chapters
0:00 – Introduction

2:34 – JAMA Cardiology Study
4:35 – LDL/ApoB vs Plaque Progression Graph
5:20 – Lizards 
5:55 – Return to Thought Puzzle

Terms
- LDL cholesterol: The cholesterol component found in circulating LDL lipoprotein particles.
- ApoB: An apolipoprotein on LDL and related particles. There is one ApoB per LDL particle.
- Lean Mass Hyper-Responder (LMHR): Defined by the union of LDL-C ≥ 200 mg/dl, HDL-C, ≥ 80 mg/dl and TG ≤ 70 mg/dl. This phenotype occurs primarily in lean people on very low-carbohydrate diets and is explained by the lipid energy model.

Nano-Chameleon: Smallest reptile on earth, about the size of a sunflower seed. Found in Madagascar. Cannot save you money on car insurance.

Pickled watermelon rind recipe: 
20 oz watermelon rind, cubed
1 tbsp sea salt kosher salt, dissolved in 1 Liter water
1 cup apple cider vinegar
1 cup allulose syrup, plain or maple/pancake (linked below)
1 tbsp whole cloves 
1 tbsp allspice (whole)
3 cinnamon sticks
1 star anise

Soak the cubed rinds for 1 hour in the salted water. Then drain. Put spices together in cheesecloth and wrap them up. Add the spices, vinegar, allulose syrup and cubed rinds to a fresh quart of water. Bring to a boil and simmer, covered, for 1 hour.

4df03_N_qVA.title: Low Carb Diet DATA Distortion
4df03_N_qVA.description:
For more on LDL and ApoB, see these prior videos:
 
- Cardiovascular Controversy: ApoB and All Cause Mortality https://youtu.be/sAjDjLJUlQQ
 
- THIS is Why There is Confusion about Lean Mass Hyper-Responders with high LDL on Ketogenic Diets: https://youtu.be/4_9UFPopl2g
 
- How to LOWER LDL on Keto. No meds! https://youtu.be/-HZEjnw4WTs
 
Supplemental Table 5 Lists Lipid Levels for the whole LCHF cohort of 2,034 participants. LDL-C levels were 3.71 mmol/l vs 3.62 mmol/l in the SD group. That’s a difference of 0.09, which can be converted to mg/dl by multiplying by 38.67. 0.09 * 38.67 = 3.48 mg/dl. Absolute mean levels of ApoB were 1.06 g/L and 1.03 g/L in the LCHF and SD groups, respectively.

For interest - and because I know the question will arise - TG mean levels in the LCHF cohort were 133 mg/dl in the LCHF group and 137 mg/dl in the SD group.

A point I do not make in the video regarding the JACC Advances paper, but that's worth considering, is that when they restrict analysis to subjects who completed at least 2 dietary questionnaires (Supplemental Table 7C), covering at least 2 days of eating (rather than 1), between group significance disappears, p = 0.34 (aHR CI: 0.49 - 8.14). This is likely due to decrease in power, but is nevertheless notable.  

With respect to my comment on the macronutrient profile of a Burger King Whopper and Fries, Nutritionix lists the following macronutrient profile(s):

Whopper: 680 kCal, 40g fat, 55g total carbohydrate, 4g fiber, 35g protein
Medium Fries: 328 kCal, 15g fat, 45g total carbohydrate, 3.4g fiber, 3.8g protein

Math:
55g fat * 9 Cal/g + 92.6g net carbohydrate*4 Cal/g + 38.8g protein*4 Cal/g = 
495 Cal fr Fat + 370.4 Cal fr Carbs + Cal + 155.2 Cal fr Pro

%Cal Carbs using Cal reported = 370.4 Cal / (1008 Cal) = 36.7%
* using the Cal sum from macros, which can and usually do vary slightly, the denominator is adjusted to 1020.6 Cal, and the %Cal Carbs is 36.3%

References
Iatan I et al. Association of a Low-carbohydrate High-fat Diet with Plasma Lipid Levels and Cardiovascular Risk. JACC Advances. 
 
Siedelmann SB et al. Dietary carbohydrate intake and mortality: a prospective cohort study and meta-analysis. The Lancet Public Health.
 
Kukuc L et al. Abstract 17808: Rapid Progression of CAD after stopping a statin and starting a ketogenic diet in a phenotypic lean mass hyper-responder. Circulation.

- "Blue whale" B roll doesn't show blue whales. We couldn't find Blue whale B-roll. But as a fun fact, they can grow up to 200 tons and their only natural predator is Orcas. Also, their latin name is Balaenoptera musculus, which means - roughly - winged whale and mouse, respectively... which may be a pun by Carl Linnaeus when he named the species.

WHAT ABOUT specific dietary components and mitochondrial fusion? …

Thanks to @AnouarElHaji on X (Twitter) for reminding me about this fantastic 2018 Nat Comm paper and asking me to comment. I LOVE community input!
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-018-05614-6 
(nb: I say remind because he points out “You used to have a YT video discussing this paper,” which I did, lol… TBT!)

Overview of this other mito fusion paper: 

A set of experiments, including a double-blinded human RCT, showing that the saturated fat stearic acid (C18:0; this annotation means 18 carbon fatty acid with 0 double bonds) “[R]apidly and robustly causes mitochondrial fusion in people within 3 h after ingestion.” 

The authors conclude: Stearic acid “C18:0 [i]s a dietary metabolite that is sensed by our bodies to control our mitochondria… [consistent with data that C18:0 may] decreas[e] cardiovascular and cancer risk.”

Rich sources of stearic acid include Tallow (~20g/100g) and Cocoa butter (34g/100g).

For more details, see THIS X post: https://x.com/nicknorwitz/status/1774760972973908132?s=20

QjPeUDR24Ec.title: I Ate 4.5 lbs of Butter in 1 Week! 2 Unexpected Twists!
QjPeUDR24Ec.description:
First... PLEASE, watch to the end... there's a twist and I want you to see it, hear me out, and contemplate the "WHY" of this video. Not the "click bait" you may be expecting...

Diet Details
Butter: 4.55 lbs butter = 2.064 kg. 

Using 102 kCal/Tbsp (14.2g/Tbsp) that's 145.35 Tbsp servings and ~ 14,825 Calories from Butter alone over the week (2,118 Butter Calories/day). 

Total daily Calories were 4,317 Calories/day. 81% Cal Fat, 18% Cal protein 1% Cal carbs. 

Based on my BMR, calculated using the Harris-Benedict equation (1,530 Cal/day) and providing 800 extra Calories/day for activity (a liberal estimate, as I resistance train up to 1 hour daily and don't current do much standard cardio), my daily surplus should have been 1,987 Calories/day and 13,909 Calories over the week. 

Using 3,500 "excess" Calories/lb I should have gained 4 lbs. But, I lost 0.8 lbs.

Lp(a) dropped 10%. TSH was ~1 (which is normal for me). Insulin post-butter week was 3.5.

0:00 - 4.5 lbs Butter in 1 Week

*Roasting nuts at home: Roasting nuts is a tricky business. If you like roasted nuts, I suggesting using temperatures at or below 265 - 285 F (130 - 140 C) for 20 minutes. The temperature sensitivity of nuts derives from their fragile omega-6 fats. But because macadamia nuts are low in omega-6, they are more stable. Even at 150 °C/ 300 °F, macadamia are okay. In fact, if you roast equal amounts of macadamia and walnuts at 300 F, the macadamia will end up with 1/30th the oxidized fats (https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25766804/).

1SjyWDXLRjw.title: Microplastics may be Poisoning You! 11 Solutions
1SjyWDXLRjw.description:
Paper: https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2309822 

0:00 - New Microplastics Paper in NEJM!
 0:47 - Methods 
1:15 - Results 
3:08 - 11 Solutions to reduce exposure 

*A criticism of the data in this paper will be that they are "associative." This was an "observational" trial, not an RCT. Technically, causality isn't proven. However, it's important to keep in mind that (1) You can't do an RCT on this topic with hard outcomes... you can't randomize a group a humans to microplastics exposure and then monitor for the outcomes of heart attack, stroke and death. (2) These data are consistent with prior work and have biological plausibility, i.e. there are data that microplastics can induce an inflammatory and immune response, signs of which we also see in this paper with the increase in immune cell activation markers and inflammatory cytokines (3) In general, the "cost" to reducing microplastics is inconvenience at most. If you choose to drink filtered tap water out of your own stainless steel bottle, rather than bottled, at absolute worst you get negligible health benefit and that water bottle doesn't end up in the ocean as pollution. 


Beat the microbead: https://www.beatthemicrobead.org/guide-to-microplastics/
PFAS free: https://pfascentral.org/pfas-free-products/

L1mMnnyJrgk.title: Oreos are the Most Potent Drug for LDL Cholesterol
L1mMnnyJrgk.description:
Paper link: https://www.mdpi.com/2218-1989/14/1/73

Chapters
0:00 – Intro
0:28 – metabolic demonstration
0:43 – Part I, the idea
1:30 – LMHR triad 
1:58 – Lipid Energy Model
3:06 – Part II, the experimental design
4:19 – Part III, results 
6:00 – results summary 
6:40 – Part IV, What’s Next? 
7:37 – Thanks and Call to Action


Aim: To tested the prediction -- consistent with the Lipid Energy Model (below) -- that adding carbohydrates (in the form of Oreo cookies) to an LMHR on a ketogenic diet would reduce LDL-C levels by a similar, or greater, magnitude than high-intensity statin therapy. 

Findings: Oreo supplementation (12 cookies/d) lowered LDL-C by 71% (273 mg/dl) in just 16 days. Rosuvastatin (20 mg/d) lowered LDL-C by 32.5% (137 mg/dl). Thus, Oreos were ~2X as potent as high-intensity statin therapy for LDL cholesterol lowering in this LMHR subject.

The Why: The LMHR phenotype has much to teach us about human metabolism, and cardiovascular disease pathophysiology. It's a new frontier that deserves further study, for the sake of the patients with this phenotype and for pure scientific curiosity! This experiment will serve as 'productive provocation,' a form of 'legit-bait' that will hopefully help prompt discussions and larger-scale experiments that need to happen.

6 select Prior publications
1/ META of RCTs (new, 1/16/24)
Sota-Mota A, Flores-Jurado Y, Norwitz NG, Feldman D, Pereira MA, Danaei G, Ludwig DS. Increased LDL cholesterol in adults with normal but not high body weight: a meta-analysis. Amer J of Clin Nutr. 2024; doi: 10.1016/j.ajcnut.2024.01.009 
 **LINK: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0002916524000091**
VIDEO: https://youtu.be/FcUUqGJBXFM

2/ n = 10 lean healthy women 
Cooper ID, Sanchez-Pizarro C, Norwitz NG, Feldman D, Kyriakidou Y, Edwards Kurtis, Petagine L, Eliiot BT, Sota-Mota A. Thyroid markers and body composition predict LDL-cholesterol change in lean healthy women on a Ketogenic Diet: Experimental support for Lipid Energy Model. Frontiers in Endocrinology. 2023; doi: 10.3389/fendo.2023.1326768 
LINK: https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fendo.2023.1326768/full
VIDEO: https://youtu.be/OpOkeXVUotU?si=vHmfywr3CH27B2w5

3/ JCL editorial

Elevated LDL cholesterol among lean mass hyper-responders on low-carbohydrate diets deserve urgent clinical attention and further research. Journal of Clinical Lipidology. 2022; doi:10.1016/j.jacl.2022.10.010 
Link: https://www.lipidjournal.com/article/S1933-2874(22)00295-1/fulltext

4/ Lipid Energy Model

0rUk3iw_RfU.title: This Vegan Documentary is a Bait and Switch
0rUk3iw_RfU.description:
What I liked: I like the concept of 'bringing the viewer along with the science.' I agree with the fact that the SAD eating pattern is problematic and that it would be an improvement to eat a whole food-based diet. I also (very much) acknowledge there are non-health related issues about food that we should have adult discussions about.

What I didn't like: 
(1) This series wasn't really about the twin study. Data were only presented, a bit, in the last of the 4 episodes. 
(2) The advertised foods (fake meat, fake cheese, fake eggs) are cast as similar/identical, but simply aren't, nor were they the basis of the participant's diets.
(3) The data presented were, I think, not all that impressive. And some data presented in the documentary could not be found in the paper, e.g. body composition.

For more on the topic of Data Misrepresentation, see our new paper: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S002231662372806X?via%3Dihub
